intro: Phoradendron pascoi, commonly known as the Pasco's mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the Viscaraceae family. It grows on the branches of various host trees, primarily in the tropical and subtropical regions of Central and South America. The plant has smooth, leathery leaves and produces small, white or pale yellow flowers. Its berries are typically red or orange, containing seeds that are dispersed by birds. Phoradendron pascoi plays a role in ecological interactions, providing food for birds and insects while also drawing nutrients from its host.
